analysis:
This is absolutely pointless. Week 2, both managers swapping tight ends who can't get you consistent points, and for what? There's no conviction here, no plan, no improvement for either side. It's like rearranging deck chairs on the Titanic.

Let's be clear about what's happened: finthefiddle, sitting at 0-1 despite having the best power score in the league, has panicked after one week and swapped Kyle Pitts for Dallas Goedert. And he's supposed to be the winner here because the trade value says so? Rubbish. Goedert's projected for 1.1 points per game the rest of the way. 1.1! Pitts is projected for 1.4. Both are in run-heavy offenses, both disappear for weeks at a time, both are injury concerns. The only difference is Goedert's older and more banged up. Brilliant business that, trading for the worse player with a worse projection because some algorithm said he's worth more. This is the fantasy football equivalent of buying a 30-year-old midfielder when you already had a 25-year-old doing the same job.

Stevenbar24 isn't celebrating either. He's 1-0, sitting pretty, and he's just swapped one inconsistent tight end for another slightly worse one. At least Pitts has youth on his side—oh wait, that doesn't matter in redraft, does it? Kirk Cousins isn't going to suddenly start force-feeding him targets. The Falcons don't use their tight end properly, everyone knows it, and this manager's just bought into four years of disappointment hoping something changes. It won't. His trading history shows he barely makes moves—four trades all-time—and this is what he does when he finally pulls the trigger? Swapping sideways at a position that'll give you eight points one week and two the next? No ambition. No ruthlessness.

The timing is what kills me most. Week 2! You've got 13 weeks until the playoffs and these two are swapping deck chairs based on one game's worth of data. Finthefiddle's made 26 trades in his career—he's an active trader, always tinkering—but activity without purpose is just noise. This is change for change's sake. Neither manager has addressed their actual problems. Neither has improved their starting lineup in any meaningful way. The projected impact is 0.2 points up or down. Negligible. You know what that tells me? This trade shouldn't have been made at all. When you're making moves in Week 2, it should be because you've identified a clear weakness and you're attacking it. Not because you're bored and fancy a different name on your roster sheet. Absolute nonsense from both of them.
